scale.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: the size or level of something, or the amount that something is happening
scale.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: A structural survey revealed the full scale of the damage.
I was shocked by the sheer scale (=very big scale) of the destruction.
Large firms benefit from economies of scale (=ways of saving money because they are big).
There has been housing development on a massive scale since 1980.
Most alternative technologies work best on a small scale.
Pollution could cause changes to weather patterns on a global scale.
We had underestimated the scale of the problem.
scale.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: a whole range of different types of people or things, from the lowest level to the highest
scale.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: Some rural schools have 50 pupils, while at the other end of the scale are city schools with nearly 5,000 pupils.
She gradually made her way up the social scale.
animals which are lower down the evolutionary scale (=the range of animals that have developed gradually over a long time)
scale.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: a system of numbers that is used for measuring the amount, speed, quality etc of something
scale.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: changes to the company’s pay scale
Your performance will be judged on a scale of 1 to 10.
We use a sliding scale (=in which prices are not firmly fixed) for charges.
The earthquakes measured 7 on the Richter scale.
scale.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: a set of marks with regular spaces between them on a tool that is used for measuring, or on the side of a mathematical drawing
scale.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: a ruler with a metric scale
scale.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: the relationship between the size of a map, drawing, or model and the actual size of the place or thing that it represents
scale.translation[0].definitions[4].exam: a map with a scale of 1:250,000
a scale drawing of the Eiffel Tower
All our models are made to scale.
scale.translation[0].definitions[5].defi: a series of musical notes that become higher or lower, with fixed distances between each note
scale.translation[0].definitions[6].defi: one of the small flat pieces of skin that cover the bodies of fish, snakes etc
scale.translation[0].definitions[7].defi: a white substance that forms on your teeth
scale.translation[0].definitions[8].defi: a white substance that forms around the inside of hot water pipes or containers in which water is boiled
scale.translation[0].note_box[0].heading: – Meaning 1: the size or level of something, or the amount that something is happening
scale.translation[0].note_box[0].section: on a large scale
This technology has been developed on a large scale in the US.
on a massive/huge scale
The drug is produced on a massive scale.
on a grand scale
The Romans built on a grand scale.
on a small scale
They started by producing and selling on a small scale.
on a human scale
Architects have been asked to redesign some of the buildings on a more human scale.
on a national scale
The survey was carried out on a national scale.
on an international scale
Preparations to deal with an outbreak of the disease are being made on an international scale.
on a global/world scale
This is a product that can be sold in high volumes on a global scale.
on an unprecedented scale
Propaganda techniques were used on an unprecedented scale.
economies of scale
Merging these departments will create economies of scale.
the full scale of something
He acknowledged that the full scale of the problem was not known.
the sheer scale of something
He was shocked by the sheer scale of the suffering he witnessed.
scale.translation[0].note_box[1].heading: – Meanings 2 & 4
scale.translation[0].note_box[1].section: At the top of the scale come the predators.
He started at the bottom of the pay scale.
At the other end of the scale, the youngest competitor was just sixteen years old.
Peasants managed their land as skilfully as some people higher up the social scale.
Bonuses are not paid to people lower down the salary scale.
At the other end of the social scale, life is a constant struggle to get enough to eat.
Birds are much lower on the evolutionary scale than dogs.
As a senior teacher, she has reached the top of her pay scale.
Some farmers prospered and moved up the social scale.
scale.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: to climb to the top of something that is high and difficult to climb
scale.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: Rescuers had to scale a 300-metre cliff to reach the injured climber.
scale.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: to make writing or a picture the right size for a particular purpose
scale.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: The writing can be scaled to any size, depending on the paper.
scale.translation[1].definitions[2].defi: if something will scale, it will continue to work well even if it is made bigger or comes to include more things
scale.translation[1].definitions[2].exam: Will this way of networking scale?
scale.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: the size or level of something, especially when this is large
scale.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: We need to recycle plastics on a much bigger scale.
No-one had anticipated the scale of the redundancies  (=that there would be so many).
scale.translation[2].definitions[1].defi: the disadvantages that a big factory, shop etc has compared with a smaller one, for example because it is more difficult to run a larger production unit
scale.translation[2].definitions[1].exam: Over a period of decades, output becomes less profitable as diseconomies of scale arise.
scale.translation[2].definitions[2].defi: the advantages that a big factory, shop etc has over a smaller one because it can spread its FIXED COSTs over a larger number of units and therefore produce or sell things more cheaply
scale.translation[2].definitions[2].exam: Joint production ventures allow for greater economies of scale.
scale.translation[2].definitions[3].defi: a list of figures used for measuring and comparing amounts
scale.translation[2].definitions[3].exam: Managers gave their opinion of the bond markets, ranked on a scale of one to ten.
a progressive scale of tax rates
